response.answer_text: Historically, the people we recognize, today, as “Vikings”, were a mix of Norse, Swedish and Danish seafarers, pirates, raiders, slavers and traders. Had the three cultures ever combined into one “Viking nation”, their sphere of influence would have, effectively, stretched from a portion of the north-east coast of North America, west to the edge of what is modern-day Moscow, and from the northern tip of modern-day Sweden (and, I think, Lappland), to the northern edge of Africa. For the better part of 300 years, the Northmen (as they were commonly referred to) effectively terrorized the European continent, until the rise of William the Conqueror brought their reign to an end in 1066 CE.

Vikings were Norse seafarers, mainly speaking the Old Norse language, who raided and traded from their Northern European homelands across wide areas of northern, central, eastern and western Europe, during the late 8th to late 11th centuries.
